author: Russell Holland
text: Nice idea, but I wish she had not only helped them out when they struggled, but followed through until they got it. Every one of these people is capable of learning this beat and with each person, there was a chance to give them the experience of learning and realizing they can do something they thought they couldn't. Every time I see someone walk away saying "I guess I suck at this" when it's something they could definitely do, it's a little sad to me. They'll probably never try again.

author: jAS Ras
text: I finally got it. If you have coordination/cogitative issues, pause the video at 0:51 and set the video Playback Speed to .25. Go grab some silverware from you kitchen as your drumsticks and keep replaying it in slo-mo over and over again once you have the beat in your head. I recommend starting with the right hand and getting that tempo down first. Then work in the foot. Once you have those two beats down consistently, introduce the left hand because I feel that is the hardest.

author: Carys Can't Dance
text: I think people who can play drums, even just the basics, take for granted just how much coordination it takes. It's a lot more complicated  than it looks. I've been playing on and off since I was a kid, and I'm mostly self-taught. I have dyspraxia (developmental coordination disorder), and it took me so long to pick it up as my brain couldn't isolate all of the separate parts. Drumming has been great for my coordination, even though it takes me a bit longer than some people to learn beats.

author: Eric K
text: Start with just the hi-hat to establish your rhythm. Then add either one of the drums, then the other. Keep that hi-hat tap going, though. You can practice just tapping on a table. Use two different parts of the hand; one sharp, like a knuckle or fingertip, and a softer, thud sound, like the palm for the bass.

author: Human Somewhat
text:
I don't play drums, but I decided to check out your channel after seeing the unassuming woman who plays down with the sickness in an older video. 

This really looks so fun and gives me a newfound appreciation for percussionists, it definitely must be harder than it looks.

This really makes me wish I could learn to play! I took piano, viola, and guitar as a kid but never stuck with it because my parents let me quit for some reason. I really wish I would have stuck with learning an instrument. Playing drums sounds so cool but I wouldn't be able to do that at home with my current living situation, since they're so loud and also need a lot of space. And I bet it costs a lot too since they're so big and so many add-on parts. 

Thanks for inspiring my musical interests though! Really makes me consider picking up an instrument again.
replies:
These days, we're lucky because there are so many options for quiet (or even silent) practice on the market. Lots of compact options, too. They aren't all cheap, but some are fairly inexpensive. And, of course, the most economical option – a practice pad – takes up almost no space at all, so it's a win/win!

If you have an interest in giving drums a try, you can find an option that will work for you! 👍🥁

Thanks for watching and commenting! No pressure but we made 30-Day Drummer with Domino for people in your situation. It's an easy way to get started drumming with even just a practice pad and sticks (you can get a full bundle plus the lessons for $117 right now).

No worries if it's not the right time for you, but you can take a look at the course here: https://www.Drumeo.com/30-Day-Drummer/

author: Jamie Macdonald
text: Watching the gears turn is enjoyable.   Such a simple beat looks and sounds so easy, but the ability to separate your limbs is the challenge.  The rub your head pat your stomach thing.
replies: And this was as basic as it gets. Pro drummers can get each limb doing completely different things. It's amazing what some like Weckl, Donati, Vinnie, etc can do. It boggles the mind.

Agree with you guys here.
I had about 2 years worth of learning and playing the electronic organ, and some years later in high school the teacher in the music class was having us try all the different instruments. I was surprised to find that my previous experience with the electronic organ had trained my brain to be able to play the simple beats but nothing complex.
I am always amazed at how excellent drummers make all things look so easy and simple.
So much harder than it looks.
I literally went to pat my belly and rub my head after reading this comment lol 😂
Exactly!
harder than one would think

The way I figured it as a guitarist that filled in for some mates was set and forget the tempo with one limb then that's one less to focus on. Mind you, it was only a practice sesh for them but the idea works for simple beats

I've never really given it much thought since I've been playing since high school, but I guess people really do have a tough time separating their limbs.  For drummers it's not something we give much thought to
For sure. As easy as the 2nd groove is to play for the average drummer, NOBODY who has never played drums can play that. Especially not relaxed 😂
